SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface SQL

public sealed interface SQL

Encapsulates a user-provided SQL statement. Klojang JDBC provides three implementations of the SQL interface. These implementations are hidden from view. Instances of them are obtained via static factory methods on the SQL interface itself. The implementations cater to different levels of parametrization of the SQL.

Named Parameters

The simplest implementation supports the use of named parameters within SQL query strings. For example: 


 SELECT *
   FROM EMPLOYEE
  WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName
    AND LAST_NAME = :lastName
  LIMIT :from, :batchSize

Named parameters are placeholders for, and will ultimately be replaced by regular JDBC parameters (that is: question marks). Thus, named parameters can and should be used wherever you would ordinarily use regular JDBC parameters. An instance of this implementation can be obtained via the SQL.simple() method. You should also preferably use this implementation for completely static SQL.

SQL Templates

A classic example of something that you often want to, but cannot parametrize with JDBC are the column(s) in the ORDER BY clause. Klojang JDBC lets you do this by providing SQL in the form of a Klojang template. That is: SQL that contains Klojang Templates variables. For example: 


 SELECT *
   FROM EMPLOYEE
  WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName
    AND LAST_NAME = :lastName
  ORDER BY ~%sortColumn% ~%sortOrder%
  LIMIT :from, :batchSize

(So, named parameters look like this: :fooBar. Klojang Templates variables look like this: ~%fooBar%.)

The workflow is as follows: Klojang Templates variables are set in the SQLSession obtained from the SQL object; named parameters are set (a.k.a. "bound") in the SQLStatement obtained from the SQLSession. Since "simple" SQL is not allowed to contain Klojang Templates variables, the SQL interface contains a few convenience methods that yield a SQLStatement object straight away, even though under the hood they still create a SQLSession object.

SQL templates can be created using the SQL.template() method. Klojang JDBC is agnostic about, and has no opinion on what gets parametrized this way. You could also parametrize the table(s) in the FROM clause for example. Klojang JDBC lets you do this in a safe manner by providing the setIdentifier() method. This method protects you against SQL injection by applying the quoting rules of the target database to the provided identifier.

SQL Skeletons

The SQL implementation obtained via SQL.skeleton() allows for very dynamically generated SQL. As with SQL templates, the SQL is provided in the form of a Klojang template (that is: it may contain Klojang Templates variables). However, SQL skeletons explicitly allow you to set template variables to SQL fragments that again contain named parameters. Klojang JDBC will register them, and you can bind them just like the named parameters in the SQL skeleton itself. This is not possible with the implementation returned by SQL.template(), since this implementation will immediately (upon instantiation) extract all parameters from the original SQL string — and leave it at that. With SQL skeletons, parameter extraction is delayed to the very last moment, just before you retrieve a SQLStatement from the SQLSession. This makes SQL skeletons somewhat less efficient, but more dynamic than SQL templates. (More precisely, it could make it worthwhile to cache SQL.template() instances, while you gain nothing by caching SQL.skeleton() instances. Note that SQL instances created from a classpath resource will anyhow always be cached, but this is to reduce file I/O.)

Also, SQL skeletons are allowed to contain nested templates while regular SQL templates are not. Nested templates are a more advanced feature of Klojang Templates which allows for even more flexibility in sculpting your SQL at runtime. For an example, see SQLSession.setNestedValue().

  • Method Details

    • staticSQL

      static SQL staticSQL(String sql)
      Returns a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables. This method actually returns the same SQL implementation as the one returned by SQL.simple(), but simply assumes that the SQL does not contain named parameters, thus saving on the cost of parsing the SQL in order to extract them.
      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL statement
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables

    • staticSQL

      static SQL staticSQL(SessionConfig config, String sql)
      Returns a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables. This method actually returns the same SQL implementation as the one returned by SQL.simple(), but simply assumes that the SQL does not contain named parameters, thus saving on the cost of parsing the SQL in order to extract them.
      Parameters:
      config - a SessionConfig object that allows you to fine-tune how Klojang JDBC operates
      sql - the SQL statement
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables

    • staticSQL

      static SQL staticSQL(Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same clazz and sqlFile arguments. This method returns the same SQL implementation as the one returned by SQL.simple(), but does so under the assumption that the SQL does not contain any named parameters, thus saving on the cost of parsing the SQL in order to extract the named parameters.
      Parameters:
      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables

    • staticSQL

      static SQL staticSQL(SessionConfig config, Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same config, clazz, and sqlFile arguments. This method returns the same SQL implementation as the one returned by SQL.simple(), but does so under the assumption that the SQL does not contain any named parameters, thus saving on the cost of parsing the SQL in order to extract the named parameters.
      Parameters:
      config - a SessionConfig object that allows you to fine-tune how Klojang JDBC operates
      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that supports neither named parameters nor Klojang Templates variables

      static SQL simple(String sql)

      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL statement
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables

    • simple

      static SQL simple(Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same clazz and sqlFile arguments. Thus, the file will be read just once.
      Parameters:
      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables

    • simple

      static SQL simple(SessionConfig config, String sql)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables.
      Parameters:
      config - a SessionConfig object that allows you to fine-tune how Klojang JDBC operates
      sql - the SQL statement
      Returns:
      an instance of an SQL implementation that behaves as described above

    • simple

      static SQL simple(SessionConfig config, Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same config, clazz, and sqlFile arguments. Thus, the file will be read just once.
      Parameters:
      config - a SessionConfig object that allows you to fine-tune how Klojang JDBC operates
      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters, but not for Klojang Templates variables

    • simpleQuery

      static SQLQuery simpleQuery(Connection con, String sql)
      Convenience method for SQL SELECT statements that do not contain Klojang Templates variables. Equivalent to: 
      
 SQL.simple(SessionConfig.getDefaultConfig(), sql).session(con).prepareQuery();
      Parameters:
      con - the JDBC connection to use
      sql - the SQL SELECT statement
      Returns:
      a SQLQuery instance that allows you to bind the named parameters in the SQL (if present) and then execute it
      See Also:
      • SQLSession.prepareQuery()

    • simpleQuery

      static SQLQuery simpleQuery(Connection con, SessionConfig config, String sql)
      Convenience method for SQL SELECT statements that do not contain Klojang Templates variables. Equivalent to: 
      
 SQL.simple(config, sql).session(con).prepareQuery();
      Parameters:
      con - the JDBC connection to use
      config - a SessionConfig object that allows you to fine-tune how Klojang JDBC operates
      sql - the SQL SELECT statement
      Returns:
      a SQLQuery instance that allows you to bind the named parameters in the SQL (if present) and then execute it
      See Also:
      • SQLSession.prepareQuery()

    • simpleInsert

      static SQLInsert simpleInsert(Connection con, String sql)

 SQL.simple(SessionConfig.getDefaultConfig(), sql).session(con).prepareInsert();
      Parameters:
      con - the JDBC connection to use

      Returns:
      a SQLInsert instance that allows you to bind the named parameters in the SQL (if present) and then execute it
      See Also:
      • SQLSession.prepareInsert()

    • simpleInsert

      static SQLInsert simpleInsert(Connection con, SessionConfig config, boolean retrieveKeys, String sql)
      Convenience method for SQL INSERT statements that do not contain Klojang Templates variables. Equivalent to: 
      
 SQL.simple(config, sql).session(con).prepareInsert();
      Parameters:
      con - the JDBC connection to use
      config - a SessionConfig object that allows you to fine-tune how Klojang JDBC operates
      retrieveKeys - whether to retrieve the keys that were generated by the database. If the database does not generate any keys for the provided INSERT statement, you must specify false, or an exception will follow when executing the statement.
      sql - the SQL INSERT statement
      Returns:
      a SQLInsert instance that allows you to bind the named parameters in the SQL (if present) and then execute it
      See Also:
      • SQLSession.prepareInsert(boolean)

      Returns:

      See Also:
      • SQLSession.prepareUpdate()

    • template

      static SQL template(Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same clazz and sqlFile arguments. Thus, the file will be read just once.
      Parameters:
      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables

    • template

      static SQL template(SessionConfig config, Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same config, clazz, and sqlFile arguments. Thus, the file will be read just once.
      Parameters:
      config - a SessionConfig object that allows you to fine-tune how Klojang JDBC operates
      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables

    • skeleton

      static SQL skeleton(String sql)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables. The template variables may be set to SQL fragments that again contain named parameters.
      Parameters:
      sql - the SQL statement
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables

    • skeleton

      static SQL skeleton(Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables. The template variables may be set to SQL fragments that again contain named parameters. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same clazz and sqlFile arguments. Thus, the file will be read just once.
      Parameters:
      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables

    • skeleton

      static SQL skeleton(SessionConfig config, Class<?> clazz, String sqlFile)
      Returns a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables. The template variables may be set to SQL fragments that again contain named parameters. The SQL is read from the specified classpath resource. The resulting SQL instance is cached and returned upon every subsequent call with the same config, clazz, and sqlFile arguments. Thus, the file will be read just once.

      clazz - a Class object that provides access to the SQL file by calling clazz.getResourceAsStream(sqlFile)
      sqlFile - the location of the SQL file
      Returns:
      a SQL implementation that allows for named parameters and Klojang Templates variables
